column2: This section covers security recommendations to follow for the configuration of Virtual Machines on an Azure subscription.
column5: Ensure that VHD's are encrypted
column6: VHD (Virtual Hard Disks) are stored in blob storage and are the old-style disks that were attached to Virtual Machines. The blob VHD was then leased to the VM. By default, storage accounts are not encrypted, and Microsoft Defender will then recommend that the OS disks should be encrypted. Storage accounts can be encrypted as a whole using PMK or CMK. This should be turned on for storage accounts containing VHDs.

column6: Ensure that all Secrets in Non Role Based Access Control (RBAC) Azure Key Vaults have an expiration time set.

column2: This section covers security recommendations to follow for the configuration and use of Azure Key Vault.
column5: Ensure the key vault is recoverable
column6: The key vault contains object keys, secrets and certificates. Accidental unavailability of a key vault can cause immediate data loss or loss of security functions (authentication, validation, verification, non-repudiation, etc.) supported by the key vault objects. It is recommended the key vault be made recoverable by enabling the "Do Not Purge" and "Soft Delete" functions.

column2: This section covers security recommendations to follow for the configuration and use of Azure Key Vault.
column5: Enable Role Based Access Control for Azure Key Vault
column6: Role assignments disappear when a Key Vault has been deleted (soft- delete) and recovered. Afterwards it will be required to recreate all role assignments. This is a limitation of the soft-delete feature across all Azure services.

column2: This section covers security recommendations to follow for the configuration and use of Azure Key Vault.
column5: Ensure that Private Endpoints are Used for Azure Key Vault
column6: Private endpoints will secure network traffic from Azure Key Vault to the resources requesting secrets and keys.

column2: This section covers security recommendations to follow for the configuration and use of Azure Key Vault.
column5: Ensure Automatic Key Rotation is Enabled Within Azure Key Vault for the Supported Services
column6: Automatic Key Rotation is available in Public Preview. The currently supported applications are Key Vault, Managed Disks, and Storage accounts accessing keys within Key Vault. The number of supported applications will incrementally increased.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure App Service Authentication is set up for apps in Azure App Service
column6: Azure App Service Authentication is a feature that can prevent anonymous HTTP requests from reaching the API app, or authenticate those that have tokens before they reach the API app. If an anonymous request is received from a browser, App Service will redirect to a logon page. To handle the logon process, a choice from a set of identity providers can be made, or a custom authentication mechanism can be implemented.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure web app redirects all HTTP traffic to HTTPS in Azure App Service
column6: Azure Web Apps allows sites to run under both HTTP and HTTPS by default. Web apps can be accessed by anyone using non-secure HTTP links by default. Non-secure HTTP requests can be restricted and all HTTP requests redirected to the secure HTTPS port. It is recommended to enforce HTTPS-only traffic.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure web app is using the latest version of TLS encryption
column6: The TLS(Transport Layer Security) protocol secures transmission of data over the internet using standard encryption technology. Encryption should be set with the latest version of TLS. App service allows TLS 1.2 by default, which is the recommended TLS level by industry standards, such as PCI DSS.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure the web app has 'Client Certificates (Incoming client certificates)' set to 'On'
column6: Client certificates allow for the app to request a certificate for incoming requests. Only clients that have a valid certificate will be able to reach the app.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure that Register with Azure Active Directory is enabled on App Service
column6: Managed service identity in App Service makes the app more secure by eliminating secrets from the app, such as credentials in the connection strings. When registering with Azure Active Directory in the app service, the app will connect to other Azure services securely without the need of username and passwords.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure that 'PHP version' is the latest, if used to run the web app
column6: Periodically newer versions are released for PHP software either due to security flaws or to include additional functionality. Using the latest PHP version for web apps is recommended in order to take advantage of security fixes, if any, and/or additional functionalities of the newer version.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure that 'Python version' is the latest stable version, if used to run the web app
column6: Periodically, newer versions are released for Python software either due to security flaws or to include additional functionality. Using the latest Python version for web apps is recommended in order to take advantage of security fixes, if any, and/or additional functionalities of the newer version.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure that 'Java version' is the latest, if used to run the web app
column6: Periodically, newer versions are released for Java software either due to security flaws or to include additional functionality. Using the latest Java version for web apps is recommended in order to take advantage of security fixes, if any, and/or new functionalities of the newer version.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure that 'HTTP Version' is the latest, if used to run the web app
column6: Periodically, newer versions are released for HTTP either due to security flaws or to include additional functionality. Using the latest HTTP version for web apps to take advantage of security fixes, if any, and/or new functionalities of the newer version.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure FTP deployments are disabled
column6: By default, Azure Functions, Web and API Services can be deployed over FTP. If FTP is required for an essential deployment workflow, FTPS should be required for FTP login for all App Service Apps and Functions.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Azure AppService.
column5: Ensure Azure Keyvaults are used to store secrets
column6: Encryption keys, Certificate thumbprints and Managed Identity Credentials can be coded into the APP service, this renders them visible as part of the configuration, to maintain security of these keys it is better to store in an Azure Keyvault and reference them from the Keyvault.

column2: This section covers security recommendations for Miscellaneous.
column5: Ensure that Resource Locks are set for Mission-Critical Azure Resources
column6: Resource Manager Locks provide a way for administrators to lock down Azure resources to prevent deletion of, or modifications to, a resource. These locks sit outside of the Role Based Access Controls (RBAC) hierarchy and, when applied, will place restrictions on the resource for all users. These locks are very useful when there is an important resource in a subscription that users should not be able to delete or change. Locks can help prevent accidental and malicious changes or deletion.
